content.description: Let <math alttext="W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> represent the number of attempted experiments to get one experiment that is not successful.
content.question: The random variable <math alttext="W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> has a geometric distribution with mean 4 and standard deviation 3.5. Which of the following is the best interpretation of the standard deviation?

choices.label: A single value randomly selected from the distribution of <math alttext="W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> will vary from 4 by 3.5 attempted experiments.

A single value randomly selected from the distribution of <math alttext="W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> will vary from 3.5 by 4 attempted experiments.
Values of <math alttext="W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> typically vary from 4 by about 3.5 attempted experiments, on average.
Values of <math alttext="W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> typically vary from 3.5 by about 4 attempted experiments, on average.

The standard deviation of a random sample of values selected from the distribution of <math alttext="W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> will be 3.5 attempted experiments.

content.answer: Values of <math alttext="W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> typically vary from 4 by about 3.5 attempted experiments, on average.

unit.text: 4: Probability, Random Variables, and Probability Distributions

skill.text: Skill 4.B: Interpret statistical calculations and findings to assign meaning or assess a claim.
